I have always thought that water was angerous with electricity because it could conduct it well, but my chemistry book, says pure water cannot conduct electricity. Could use a quick aswer.

I have always thought that water was angerous with electricity because it could conduct it well, but my chemistry book, says pure water cannot conduct electricity. Could use a quick aswer.

 Your chemistry book is correct. Pure water is a great insulator of electricity. The thing is, water always has impurities, and it is these impurities that can conduct electricity.

I have always thought that water was angerous with electricity because it could conduct it well, but my chemistry book, says pure water cannot conduct electricity. Could use a quick aswer.

 
 Pure water lacks dissolved ions that can carry electrical charges because of its covalent bonding. Add to it some ionic species, such as salt, and it will conduct electricity.

I have always thought that water was angerous with electricity because it could conduct it well, but my chemistry book, says pure water cannot conduct electricity. Could use a quick aswer.
Pure water lacks dissolved ions that can carry electrical charges because of its covalent bonding. Add to it some ionic species, such as salt, and it will conduct electricity.

 JP hits the nail on the head here, omega. Although water autodissociates to 
 10^-7 M H+ and 10^-7 M OH-, this is much too low an ionic concentration to produce significant conductivity. Tap water and swimming pool water of course contain plenty of dissolved ions, so they'll conduct electricity.
